Measuring the Informal Sector 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  While the economies of developing member countries (DMCs) continue to grow rapidly, 
recent research has found that inequalities in standards of living are widening and the benefits 
of growth are bypassing the poor. The special chapter of the Key Indicators of Developing Asian 
and  Pacific  Countries  20071,  based  on  household  income  and  expenditure  survey  data  of 
DMCs, provides evidence that absolute inequality has increased in many countries in Asia, and 
that the incomes of the rich have grown faster than those of the poor that the rich have grown 
richer faster than the poor. One way to address this problem is to improve the labor market 
opportunities for workers, because employment is the main avenue out of poverty. To cope with 
poverty, the poor engage in informal employment such as subsistence jobs, secondary jobs, 
and occasional jobs. This type of labor has grown in many DMCs, making the informal sector a 
major component of their economies. The Interregional Cooperation on the Measurement of 
Informal Sector and Informal Employment (ICMISIE) project2 estimates that the informal sector 
accounts for more than 50% of nonagricultural employment and about 30% of nonagricultural 
gross domestic product in many countries. Consequently, understanding and measuring the 
informal sector is vital to improving the labor market opportunities for the poor. 
 
2.   This regional technical assistance3 (RETA) proposes contributing to the understanding 
and measurement of the informal sector by (i) examining existing data collection strategies and 
identifying the most  appropriate  and sustainable strategy  for DMCs; (ii) assisting DMCs in 
defining  workable  procedures  in  integrating  data  collected  from  the  informal  sector  in  the 
compilation of national accounts; and (iii) conducting data-intensive research on the relationship 
between poverty and the informal sector. The RETA design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Measurement of the informal sector is difficult because of its nature and composition. 
The informal sector comprises (i) households with at least some market production; and (ii) 
production units with low levels of organization and technology, and with unclear distinction 
between  labor  and  capital  or  between  household  and  production  operations.  Other  typical 
characteristics of these units are high mobility and turnover, seasonality, lack of recognizable 
features  for identification, and reluctance to share information. These units usually are not 
covered by establishment or enterprise surveys, because they are not included in the sampling 
frames for these surveys.4 However, these units might be covered by household surveys, which 
usually do not include questions pertaining to production. Because of these issues, informal 
sector statistics are not collected through the regular survey system of national statistical offices 
(NSOs). Therefore, informal sector statistics can be compiled only through special surveys for 
this purpose. 
 
                                               
1  Asian Development Bank. 2007, Key Indicators of Developing Asia and Pacific Countries, Manila 
2  ICMISIE is a multiyear and multilateral development account project of the United Nations, with the Economic and 
Social Commission for the Asia and Pacific as the lead agency. This project is being implemented in Economic and 
Social Commission for the Asia and Pacific, Economic and Social Commission for West Asia, and Economic 
Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean in close collaboration with the United Nations Statistics Division, 
International Labor Organization, Economic Commission for Europe, Economic Commission for Africa, and the 
Delhi Group (United Nations Expert Group on Informal Sector Statistics).  
3  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 17 July 2007. 
4 The coverage of the list of establishments or enterprises (or the sampling frame) usually depends on a certain 
threshold of employment size or gross revenue.

2   
4.  Since data on the informal sector and informal employment are not available regularly, if 
at all, the national accounts statistics cannot cover this sector, resulting in distorted estimates of 
the structure of the economy. This lack of information also hinders the understanding of policy 
makers—in government, the private sector, and the public—about many social and economic 
issues related to informal sector activities, such as lack of social protection; limited access to 
credit, training, and markets; and differentials in wages and working conditions. As such, the 
policies and interventions that are formulated and implemented to reduce poverty by generating 
decent work might not result in the desired outcome. 
 
5.  The collection of data on the informal sector can take many approaches—independent 
surveys, mixed household–enterprise surveys, labor force or other household surveys, or the 
expansion of coverage of establishment surveys and economic censuses. Developing countries 
with limited public funds cannot sustain many of these approaches, because conducting regular 
national surveys requires sizeable budgets. However, many of these same countries have large 
informal sectors and informal employment that need to be measured.   
 
6.  The  available  statistics  for  those  few  countries  that  have  incorporated  questions 
pertaining to the informal sector into their labor force surveys (LFSs) might not be comparable 
with other countries because of differences in definition and concepts. The definition of the 
informal sector was established at the 15th International Conference of Labor Statisticians, 
while the definition of informal employment was established at the 17th conference. However, 
countries  have  not  applied  these  definitions  uniformly. An  examination  of  the  International 
Labour  Organization  database  reveals  differences  in  countries’  practices,  data  collection 
coverage,  operational  definitions,  and  data  collection  methods.  For  example,  while  non-
registration  of  an  enterprise  is  one  of  the  factors  used  to  determine  if  an  enterprise  or 
establishment  is  part  of  the  informal  sector,  registration  requirements  vary  widely  across 
countries and might change over time within a country. Another factor is employment size. It is 
often  assumed that small firms usually  are not well organized  and have limited access to 
technology  and  therefore,  should  be  classified  under  the  informal  sector.  However,  this 
assumption is not accurate for all enterprises, especially those that specialize in outsourcing 
information technology. In addition, governments determine the employment size threshold for 
other purposes, such as taxation and industry policies for some countries.  
 
7.  Recognizing that a standard definition cannot be imposed  on all countries, ICMISIE 
adopted  a  unified  data  collection  strategy  that  uses  household  unincorporated  enterprises 
engaged in market production (HUEMs)  as the unit of  analysis. This  strategy captures  all 
relevant enterprise characteristics for identifying an informal sector enterprise based on at least 
two sets of criteria—the country’s, as well as that of the International Conference of Labor 
Statisticians and the United Nations Expert Group on Informal Sector Statistics (or Delhi Group), 
which was constituted in 1997 to harmonize national definitions of the informal sector to improve 
international  comparability.  This  approach  is  different  from the  usual  survey  approach  that 
selects informal sector enterprises based on a set of predetermined criteria. 
 
 8.   The  unified  data  collection  strategy  proposed  a  two-stage  sampling  design  for  the 
survey. The first stage would be an enhanced LFS that identifies HUEMs and their location. This 
could  be  used  as  a  sampling  frame  for  the  second  stage  and  for  estimating  informal 
employment. The second stage would be a survey of the HUEMs that collects statistics on

s ervices statistics. As the first stage of selection is designed to estimate labor force statistics, 
the HUEMs might be distributed unevenly for the second stage selection. Hence, the strategy

3
might result in less-efficient estimates than those from independent informal sector surveys. 
Methodological research, therefore, is needed to address this important issue. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The RETA’s intended impact is to contribute to the increase in evidence-based policy 
making for poverty reduction. For outcomes, the RETA is expected to (i) provide NSOs with a 
sound strategy for collecting data from the informal sector; (ii) support the integration of informal 
sector  survey  results  into  the  compilation  of  national  accounts  statistics;  and  (iii)  enable 
agencies  involved  in  planning, monitoring,  and  evaluating  poverty-related  policies  to  better 
understand the relationships between poverty and the informal sector. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  To  achieve the desired  outcomes, the RETA will have three major components: (i) 
development of the data collection strategy, (ii) data collection and analysis, and (iii) economic 
and  methodological  research  using  the  informal  sector  survey  data.  The  RETA  will  be 
implemented in three countries—Armenia, Bangladesh, and Indonesia. These countries were 
selected because they have (i) an existing LFS with a sufficiently large sample of households, 
(ii) an informal sector that is perceived to be growing, and (iii) not been supported by ICMISIE.   
 
11.  The unified data collection strategy that ICMISIE is implementing seems to be the most 
appropriate for DMCs with limited budgets for surveys. However, because the LFS sampling 
designs  vary  across  countries,  methodological  studies  have  to  be  conducted  for  each 
participating DMC to optimize the current LFS design and to develop the sampling design for 
the second-stage survey (HUEMs survey) such that it can be conducted by NSOs with limited 
budget. Appropriate estimation procedures, including survey weights, also will be established.  
Existing survey instruments for the LFS will have to be revised to include variables necessary 
for identification of HUEMs in the second stage.   
 
12.  Limited funds and technical advice will be provided to participating NSOs to cover the 
additional questions for the first stage of the unified data collection strategy, as well as the 
preparation, conduct, and processing of the HUEMs survey (second stage). Survey data will be 
analyzed to generate informal sector statistics and to provide data support for the second and 
third components of the RETA.  
 
13.  The United Nations Statistics Division is updating the 1993 system of national accounts 
to  provide  guidance  on  the  treatment  of  the  informal  sector  in  national  accounts.  These 
guidelines  will  be  studied  to  allow  them  to  be  implemented  in  the  selected  DMCs. 
Implementation  will  involve  the  determination  of  data  items  required  in  the  compilation  of 
national accounts, and incorporation of them into the survey instruments for LFS and HUEMs. 
Estimation procedures also must be developed in accordance with the guidelines. Training will 
be provided to concerned NSO staff. The resulting data series will be validated and discussed 
with concerned government agencies.

14.  An analytical model that will map the complex links between the informal sector and the 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
incidence of poverty will be developed using the results of the HUEMs survey. By comparing 
 
income differentials of workers in the formal and informal sectors, research has shown a clear 
link between poverty and employment in the informal sector. However, research has not yet

4   
determined (i) the number of working poor, (ii) the number employed in the informal sector, and 
(iii) the prevalence of poor in the informal sector compared with the formal sector. The research 
on poverty and the informal sector that will be conducted under this RETA will address these 
issues.  If  the  LFS  and  the  household  income  and  expenditure  survey  share  common 
respondent households, these surveys can be linked and these questions can be answered 
directly. Otherwise, alternative statistical methods will be explored.  
 
15.  The research papers, data collection strategy, survey instruments, and other relevant 
materials that will be produced will be consolidated into a publication that will be circulated 
among the NSOs and other relevant agencies in the region. To disseminate the important 
results of this RETA, the publication also will be used as training material for workshops that will 
be conducted for key staff of other NSOs with growing informal sectors. These workshops may 
be  held  in  subregional  centers  to  reduce  travel  costs.  RETA  consultants  and  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) staff with strong backgrounds in analyzing household survey data, as 
well  as  extensive  experience  in  designing  and  conducting  sample  surveys,  will  serve  as 
resource speakers for these workshops. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The RETA will cost an estimated $500,000. This total covers consulting services and 
financial support that will be provided to the NSOs of participating DMCs for the conduct and 
processing of HUEMs surveys, cost of publication, and training workshops. The RETA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s technical assistance funding program. The detailed cost 
estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA, the administration of which will be the 
responsibility  of  ADB’s  Economics  and  Research  Department  (ERD).  The  RETA  will  be 
implemented over 3 years from January 2008 to December 2010. ERD will coordinate with 
participating NSOs in developing a comprehensive schedule of activities for conducting and 
analyzing the HUEMs survey. Moreover, ERD will coordinate with ICMISIE, including the Delhi 
Group, to minimize duplication of tasks and optimize the RETA’s limited resources.   
 
18.  The amount of financial support for conducting and processing the HUEMs survey in 
participating DMCs will be decided in consultation with the NSOs based on the sample size, 
which will be determined from the results of the LFS. A memorandum of agreement will be 
drawn up with the NSOs specifying the activities that will be undertaken for this RETA, as well 
as the financial and technical support that ADB will provide. ADB’s support will include the 
provision of technical advice for sampling design, preparation of survey instruments, training of 
enumerators and supervisors, and methodology for incorporating the HUEMs survey into the 
national accounts.  
 
19.  The RETA will finance 24 person-months of consulting services (international, 6 person-
months; national, 18 person-months). The consultants will be selected and engaged individually, 
in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time 
to time). The terms of reference of the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Measuring the Informal Sector, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Appendix 3  9
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE OF CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultant: Sampling Design Expert (2 person-months, intermittent) 
1.  The  international  consultant  should  have  a  strong  background  in  designing  and 
evaluating  sample  surveys  of  national  coverage.  The  consultant  must  have  extensive 
experience  in  working  with  household  surveys  of  national  coverage,  especially  labor  force 
surveys. Preferably, the consultant should have some experience in designing surveys that will 
collect data on the informal sector. 
 
2.  In particular, the consultant will  
 
(i)  assist the project officer in reviewing the existing sampling strategies for the 
informal sector; 
 
(ii)  based on the review (i) and the discussions with selected developing member 
countries (DMCs), prepare the most appropriate sampling strategy for collecting 
data on the informal sector;  
 
(iii)  work  with  the  national  statistical  offices  (NSOs)  of  selected  DMCs  in 
implementing (ii), and participate as resource speaker in workshops and training, 
if necessary; 
 
(iv)  suggest refinements of the sampling strategy after completion of data collection; 
and 
 
(v)  prepare a report on items (i) to (iv). 
 
B.  International Consultant: National Accounts Expert (2 person-months, intermittent) 
3.  The  international  consultant  should  be  a  statistician  with  a  strong  background  in 
developing  methods  for  compiling  national  accounts  statistics.  The  consultant  must  have 
extensive experience in analyzing household surveys and, preferably, a working knowledge of 
the statistical systems of the DMCs covered in this regional technical assistance (RETA).  
 
4.  In particular, the consultant will 
 
(i)  review the updated 1993 system of national accounts that was developed by the 
United Nations Statistics Division to provide guidance on the treatment of the 
informal sector in national accounts; 
 
(ii)  develop the list of data items needed for incorporating the contributions of the 
informal sector in national accounts, and work with NSOs of participating DMCs 
to ensure that all these data items are incorporated in the questionnaires for the 
labor force survey and household unincorporated enterprises engaged in market 
production (HUEMs) survey; 
  
(iii)  work  with  NSOs  of  participating  DMCs  in  developing  a  suitable  method  for 
incorporating the informal sector survey results in the national accounts;

10  Appendix 3 
(iv)  act as resource speaker in the training workshop for key staff of selected DMCs; 
and 
 
(v)  assist  the  staff  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  Economics  and  Research 
Department  (ERD)  in  writing  a  paper  for  the  prospective  publication  on 
measuring the informal sector. 
 
C.  International Consultant: Econometrician (2 person-months, intermittent) 
5.  The  international  consultant  should  be  an  economist  with  a  strong  background  in 
econometrics  and  poverty  analysis.  The  consultant  must  have  extensive  experience  in 
analyzing  household  surveys,  particularly  on  poverty  and  the  informal  sector  and  informal 
employment. 
 
6.  In particular, the consultant will 
 
(i)  develop an empirical framework for analyzing the relationship between poverty 
and the informal sector; 
 
(ii)  based on (i), work with the national consultant in analyzing the informal sector 
surveys; 
 
(iii)  act as resource speaker in the training workshop for key NSO staff in selected 
DMCs; and 
 
(iv)  assist ERD staff in writing a paper for the prospective publication on measuring 
the informal sector.  
 
D.  National Consultant: Statistician (18 person-months, intermittent) 
7.  The national consultant should have a strong background in statistics, extensive work 
experience  with  household  survey  data  (including  detailed  knowledge  of  the  sample  and 
questionnaire design of survey data), and sufficient practical knowledge on the informal sector. 
The national consultant must be adept at using statistical analysis software.  
 
8.  Under the guidance and supervision of the project officer, the national consultant will  
 
(i)  assist the project officer in the coordination of survey work and research for the 
informal sector;  
 
(ii)  assist in the preparation of the survey instruments and in the organization of 
workshops and training; 
 
(iii)  under the supervision of the econometrician, analyze the results of the informal 
sector surveys to examine the relationship between poverty and the informal 
sector; 
 
(iv)  assist in the preparation of the prospective publication (book) on measuring the 
informal sector;

(v)  support a web-enabled system for the dissemination of materials on the informal 
sector by organizing relevant materials and outputs of the research, training, and 
surveys; and 
 
(vi)  assist in the preparation of the final report of this project.
